@JonnyHAuckland1 @andrexnoel @PCarterClimate Not imaginary at all. We can already see with clean energy capacities (along with EVs) that the growth rates are huge, i.e. exponential. Billions are already being invested in CO2 capture and storage, and similar trends will be seen when that technoloy is scaled up (soon).

@JackiePaper12 @andrexnoel @PCarterClimate How are we on track for a worst case scenario? Clean energy capacities are growing *exponentially* worldwide. Ditto for electric vehicles. The compound annual growth rates are huge. We can probably expect the same trends for CO2 capture and storage when they get scaled up (soon).

@GraphexGroup EV sales are growing exponentially as costs decline and the technology improves. On current trends, it's likely that 1/3rd of new cars will be electric by 2028, and traditional ICE cars will be largely obsolete in the 2040s. Charging stations are likewise expanding exponentially.

@PeterDiamandis 15 years is very optimistic. A few minor aspects of the aging process might be reversible by then, such as hair loss, joint/muscle problems, skin wrinkles, and so on, but the really exciting breakthroughs for extending lifespan are surely further out.

@dlature So after 2100, once the transition is complete, we will no longer need to worry about the collapse of civilisation. Instead of just trying to "survive", we will rebuild our civilisation into something truly great, aided by super-powerful AIs that will exist by then.

10/10

@dlature So we don't have to "delay" a more sustainable system until 2100. The transition is already underway. By 2100 it will be largely perfected, with 100% clean energy, many gigatons of historical emissions sequestered, other issues tackled such as recycling/circular economies.

9/10

@dlature The many examples listed previously won't be enough to prevent 2°C of global warming, but they can help to slow the longer-term trend, and hold society together long enough to avoid a collapse of civilisation. 

8/10

@dlature Many other developments are taking place around the world, from mass reforestation programs, to innovations in smart city technology, heat-reflecting paint on walls/rooftops, direct air capture + conversion of CO2 to useful products, seagrass restoration, the list goes on.

7/10

@dlature Then there's genetic engineering of crops, with many recent examples of dramatic improvements in yield. We're talking 50%+ and extreme drought tolerance. Alongside that, new indoor food production methods, vertical/urban farms, hydroponics, etc. managed and optimised by AI.

6/10

@dlature Cultured meat, and other lab-grown food products, could drastically reduce GHG emissions, as well as water and land use. This industry is forecast to explode in the next 10-20 years and will revolutionise the agricultural sector.

5/10

@dlature Carbon pricing initiatives are growing in number, with about 20% of the world's emissions now having a tax or other pricing system in place. This could reach 40% by 2030, and 75% by 2040, looking at the projected trend.

4/10

@dlature So we need to work as hard as we can, within the limits of our current political/economic systems, to avoid further temperature rises. However, there is reason for hope, with many encouraging trends that suggest we *can* prevent the worst-case climate scenarios.

2/10

@dlature Perhaps our tweet should be clarified!

In an ideal world, obviously we'd decarbonise to avoid the 1.5 and 2°C limits. 

But *realistically*, that won't happen, unless a Green Party is elected in every G20 country. Climate Action Tracker projects 97% chance of >2°C.

[cont.] 1/10

@coldreactive Hopefully we can upgrade to non-biological bodies in the longer term. Future pandemics might actually serve to accelerate such a transition.

We might also reach a Singularity-type scenario where new vaccines with near-100% efficacy can be mass-deployed on very short timescales.
